text:
I have seen some instances of websites getting punished by Google's core updates when they used subfolders for content on vastly different topics.

Think websites with a /health AND /celeb AND /sex-life subfolders.

Difficult to say anything for certain here, but during one of the core updates in 2019 we've seen sites with such structure punished big time, while competitors with <http://health.example.com|health.example.com> and <http://celeb.example.com|celeb.example.com> did much better.

I don't have the data on hand but it's something I'd recommend looking into before making that call.

text: Hi, folx! I’m exploring options to change my company’s blog to a library style — instead of publication in reverse chronological order (thanks, <@UJG9WTEKG>!). Can you think of companies that found good ways of doing this? Many thanks!

elements.text: Hi, folx! I’m exploring options to change my company’s blog to a library style — instead of publication in reverse chronological order (thanks,
!). Can you think of companies that found good ways of doing this? Many thanks!

text:
I’m biased, but I like our <https://www.contentkingapp.com/academy/|Academy approach> which is our library. It’s copied by a few other companies in the SEO and Content Marketing space now, maybe that’s some form of validation :sweat_smile:

We do also have <https://www.contentkingapp.com/blog/|a blog with chronological order> for content that fits right in there, such as feature announcement, interviews, news — everything that makes sense to be filed away in chronological order. There’s no evergreen content in there.

attachments.title: ContentKing Academy: Get the most out of your content
attachments.text: Learn how to get the most out of your content with ContentKing Academy's detailed reference guides.

text:
Hey <@UJ94SJMG9> Like Patrick said, it depends on what kind of marketing manager you are. I manage social media platforms and create content. Since I use 3rd part apps for scheduling post I am able to oversee them when they go live and fine tune them with tags if needed.

I am on the phone a lot. This means I am diving into IG stories, Reels and engagement from the audience. I generally do this 3 times a day. Morning, Afternoon, Early evening. In between this I am creating content.

text:
Those of you creating content briefs:

Do you create briefs for your clients to use (so the clients can give them to their own in-house writers)?

If so, do you do anything differently in your briefs than you would for briefs to be used by your org’s writers (freelance, in-house, whatever capacity)? We often include Clearscope reports for _our_ writers so they can grade their copy, but we’re concerned about sharing them with clients and their writers (the concern being, what’s to stop them from just licensing their own version of CS or other tool)?

text: For in-house _writers_ who aren't necessarily SMEs, I suggest materials they should read/reference and suggest people they should reach out to for quotes etc.

text:
Yeah, I would say in-house definitely should be getting more resources. 

If you're providing briefs externally for clients to use, I would try and understand what the goal of them are. If it's to provide a service with minimal interaction from your end, a detailed brief might be better (ie. Including the clear scope, etc). However, if you want to have more involvement, I'd include only what's necessary and then create a process for getting the end result to measure against expectations.

elements.text:

However, if you want to have more involvement, I'd include only what's necessary and then create a process for getting the end result to measure against expectations.

text: <@U019E2RJD9Q>

Probably important to distinguish between a content brief and a topic model here. If your briefs are simply a list of keywords to use and a title, then of course you're not adding any value on top of what many tools can give the client. And you probably should just tell them client to use their own content grading solution.

More likely, you're doing some work to go fetch additional data and produce a more concrete deliverable, whether it's for an internal writer or to actually give it to the client.

I'm obviously biased here but that's the entire reason we built Content Harmony - to produce better deliverables, _then_ follow it up with optimization via the underlying topic model.

text:
Hey folks :wave:

I’m working on an Ahrefs piece on *content calendars* and I got all my bases covered (what they are/how they work/etc.), but I could do with some help to think about non-obvious angles or topics I haven’t considered.

For example → *what do you wish you had known about content calendars that you only learned by trial-and-error working with one?* 

_(mine would be: the importance to build a 1-month backlog of pieces ready to go, so that we could make sure not to miss a publishing date due to scheduling/ illness/ unforeseen stuff)_

text:
When I was at CXL, we found that the raw number of posts in a given stage (e.g., outline, draft) wasn't a useful indicator of how solid the pipeline was, for two reasons:

1. We didn't know how likely it was that those authors would actually hit their deadlines (since they were mostly guest authors).
2. We didn't have immediate, high-level visibility into the total quality of the pipeline. (We'd have some posts in progress that we were 50/50 on whether they'd "make it"; others we couldn't wait to read.)
We scored posts on a 1-5 scale for "likelihood to get done" and "post quality," then totaled those figures for each column.

That was a better way to, at a glance, look at the "Outline" column in a Trello board and know immediately how strong the pipeline was (because we could trend numbers over time and correlate with what actually got out).

Full disclosure: We never got this past a beta stage for this process; we saw the value but hadn't automated it all by the time I left.

We scored posts on a 1-5 scale for "likelihood to get done" and "post quality," then totaled those figures for each column.

That was a better way to, at a glance, look at the "Outline" column in a Trello board and know immediately how strong the pipeline was (because we could trend numbers over time and correlate with what actually got out).

text:
For smaller teams (if applicable to your piece's audience):

A content calendar isn't a good stand-in for content strategy. Strategy drives calendar. Don't expect either one to do the other's job.

text: I’m trying to make the move from freelance content writing to full-time in-house work and have a couple of interviews coming up. Any interview suggestions from people who’ve made this move or hired someone making it?

elements.text: I’m trying to make the move from freelance content writing to full-time in-house work and have a couple of interviews coming up. Any interview suggestions from people who’ve made this move or hired someone making it?

text: Honestly no specific tips, but good luck. Are you going in-house with a client? I worked with my current employer as a freelancer for for about a year and a half. It was such a great transition because they already knew my worth. If you have a client you love, consider keeping your ear to the ground about any positions they have in their marketing department. You could have a big foot in the door that way.

elements.text: Honestly no specific tips, but good luck. Are you going in-house with a client? I worked with my current employer as a freelancer for for about a year and a half. It was such a great transition because they already knew my worth. If you have a client you love, consider keeping your ear to the ground about any positions they have in their marketing department. You could have a big foot in the door that way.

text:
in-house roles sometimes require you to speak about things that freelancers don’t usually handle, like performance metrics, SEO strategies, and getting backlinks.

have a plan to address those questions

text: Has anyone else noticed a surge in web traffic over the past few days? I have 3 different clients who all saw increases of 500%, One client specifically drew clicks from Virginia, another is spread out globally...

elements.text: Has anyone else noticed a surge in web traffic over the past few days? I have 3 different clients who all saw increases of 500%, One client specifically drew clicks from Virginia, another is spread out globally...

text:
I recently hired two writers transitioning from freelance. My #1 worry was they would prioritize things like output, number of words, keywords covered etc. over quality. But some orgs may actually care about those things, so you should take a hard look at their existing content and figure what it is that they are looking for.

Knowledge of topics over keywords, information architecture and other general SEO concepts can be beneficial for sure. Same obv goes for working with personas and outlines.

As always, if you can take the time to look at their existing content and show that you understand their current needs and goals during the interview, they will like it.

text:
One of the things that I have learned from trial and error when handling content calendar is ensuring that there are enough pieces tied to each of the category pages that we have.

For example, we realised that 80% of our content was written for a specific category page (Small Business Tips) leaving categories like Insights and Business Experience dry.

Our new strategy is to not just prioritise content for each persona, but also ensure that there's a post for every category as well.

elements.text:

text:
This is all great, thanks. Right now we just have 1 content brief format that we deploy for all use cases (our writers & external client writers) but we’re running into situations where it might benefit us having different versions. But we also want our clients’ content to succeed and rank, so it seems like withholding a content grading tool from them would handicap the whole effort.

Our briefs are pretty thoroughly researched regardless. Any emphasis on a grading tool comes in at the end, but depending on whose writing, they might weave it into the draft process early on.

Anyhow, it’s an ongoing convo. Appreciate all the input.

text: I just hired someone making this transition (although they had worked in-house in the past). The advice above is great, especially agree with <@U016BDEQ40J> because that’s where 100% pure freelancers can get caught up the most. But you also have strength where perhaps those with in-house content marketing experience don’t, and that’s in really really high-quality writing and a maturity in the way you request, accept, and synthesize feedback from key stakeholders. You should also lean heavily on domain expertise that perhaps others won’t have. I find freelancers tend to ramp more quickly as well, since they’re used to adjusting to new clients, new projects, new styles of working and have their own process for getting stuff done. So if they’re looking for someone who can ramp fast because their content needs are immediate, that can be a big selling point.
